UPDATE AS OF 20/02/15
Apparently, the failure of Molyneux and Godus has grown more and more popular in the last month. I believe these 3 articles might be interesting for anyone still convinced Godus is worth any money at all:

http://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2015/02/13/peter-molyneux-interview-godus-reputation-kickstarter/

http://www.theguardian.com/technology/2015/feb/13/peter-molyneux-game-designer-interview-godus

http://www.pcgamer.com/godus-designer-admits-kickstarter-promises-likely-cant-be-kept/

Original review:

I bought Godus around a year ago. Its simple and colourful graphics, the User Interface and the many various features intrigued me. However, as many users said, the game has been on early access for ages and there was more re-designing than actual improvement of the game.

Many features were removed, some were later re-added, glitches regarding savegames occured and forced the user to restart from 0 - when it wasn't an update to mess up with it in the first place. Overall, what disappointed me the most is that 22cans has been playing with its fans for a while, giving an awful support which made me almost hate the game, and abandon it even before I received the (is there a pejorative of late?) reply. And as if that happened once, months after giving up with Godus I decided to get back to it, only to see that unrealistic features that I didn't even want (like the mixed and multiethnic people of a presumably paleolithic society??) were added. I begged for support and gave availability in case it was required to mod the game on my own to restore the caucasic-only population. I even explained my reasons, saying that it was good to add up races but that a player should get to pick which ones he wants and doesn't want - regardless the colour. The response I received (about 2 months later) was a copy&paste, and guess what? The writing was so bogus and automatic that it rang a bell in my head, I went checking the older email from my first ticket and they were identical!

Apart from the lacking, dumb, and almost self-generated support"
date: the game itself is poor as I mentioned above. You can enjoy it maybe for about 20 hours in case you have little experience with God videogames (as the undersigned)
recommended: then it gets repetitive and pointless. I suggest anyone wishing to play a game of this sort to rely on the comments of god-games enthusiasts/aficionados in order to find a way better (and likely older) one.\n\nTo sum up: It seemed promising
hoursPlayed: but knowing that this game has been on early access for 16 months with little improvement
voteText:
buying it at the moment would be a waste of money. DON'T LET THE VIVID COLOURS AND CARTOON-LIKE GRAPHICS TRICK YOU INTO PURCHASING. 22cans has probably hired good graphic artists in order to show off a slideshow of artworks that don't represent their game at all. Get the Maxim game SPORE instead if you really want to experience how it feels to be a God.

Random features that should have been implemented (in my opinion):

-Aspects allowing the player to personalise and customise his or her followers and their society (morphology or and climate of the starting area

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Sadly, it is time to write my very first negative review. And before someone chastises me for my 3.5 game hours on steam, please note that this does not include my offline gaming time while I am travelling, cause this is the best time to wait and gather belief without being connected to steam. Sounds sad, I know.

I was one of the first to back this game on steam, because I was absolutely enamoured by the idea of painting the world to your desires, helping your little citizens to grow, explore and expand. The idea for the game is great, but the development is not. And to add insult to injury, the devs actually noted in the initial release that the game is like 45 or 49% ready. This got me thinking optimistically - good, so it will be finished soon. 15 months later, the game hasn't progressed decently enough to merit a purchase.

Stay away from it like it is a forest fire till they actually finish it. After that it may well be a decent experience. I know I had fun with it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love god games and I have loved Peter Molyneux games - Black & White and Fable in particular. I was very excited when I saw a gameplay video on gamespot with Molyneux playing the game on ipad; looked great and fun.

This beta is very poor at the moment - it lacks any gameplay element apart from land flattening by clicking; its like a scaled back version of populous with lots of mouse clicking and prettier graphics.

As you expand your village and field of influence you soon realise that 1. you have to create a flat featureless landscape for villagers to build houses on and 2. the villages are empty of life unless you click the houses for the villagers to come out which they do to build more houses then they wander back in to their houses or sit around for a bit and die. Oh and theres no way to make them go in a house so you just wait for them to die. Though there's no discernable effect for you if they do die.

Weirdly for a god sim, in order to advance you collect cards from chests which act as your resources, when you get enough cards required your civilisation advances. Its a mechanic which removes your villagers from interacting with the land and environment - empty flatness is the result.

Ever played a dying MMO with formerly bustling areas empty of activity? Godus quickly feels devoid of life and depressing to play.

My fault for not waiting for reviews, but I trusted what the trailers seemed to offer; leave alone and play something with a soul and a less painful UI mechanic. I wish I could get a refund as I feel tricked into paying £15 - I'd gladly put this £15 as an extra thank you to the makers of a good indie game Starbound/Faster Than Light/Fez come to mind.

Did I say empty and flat enough? Oh I said it again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Godus: 13 months later

Godus is a LOT better than it was when it was first made available on Steam, but it still has a long way to go, and I'm not sure it's going to survive the trip.

I will not expound on the soul-crushing gameplay issues that were rampant in version 1.x.x of the game, as many of them have been fixed. The issue now seems to be one of...waiting.

I have never seen a game that requires quite this much waiting. You will not notice it so much in the first 10 to 20 minutes of play, but as the hours go on, you will find yourself collecting your belief, sacrificing your followers for gems, sending out builders to contruct new buildings, sculpting a tiny piece of your land, then realizing you have 45-60 minutes (!!!) to wait until you can do anything else, because you need to wait for more followers to spawn, more belief to generate, and for those buildings to finish contruction. Once, the game told me I would have to wait over A DAY for another farmer to spawn.

In the developer commentary, they say that you should use this time to go treasure hunting" or on voyages

recommended: and treasure hunting for stickers takes all of 5 minutes...if you have enough Belief to move the land around looking

reviewText:
Early Access Review

OK so after playing the game for 85hrs I'm ready to give my first review on steam.

DO NOT BUY THIS GAME AT FULL PRICE. (If you only have to spend a couple dollars or pounds to buy it then yes its worth wasting a couple days playing)

I feel like I'm being abused by the developers of this game.

Constant swapping between worlds to send hundreds of followers to the pit of doom just to move the game forward at a more reasonable pace.

I saw the kickstarter for this and got really excited so when the opportunity came along to buy it for a couple pound I jumped in.

Now let me be clear this is a mobile game to make money out of muppets, this is not a PC game and should not be marketed as such.

The game drags along at an agonising pace because the devs have slowed it down to a crawl to make money from mobile users.

You will spend hours killing followers to get gems to then buy stuff to speed it along.

You will spend hours roaming the map collecting resourses with your mouse, because auto collection of resources costs gems (and ore and wheat auto collection is not available to me after 85 hrs of play)

I'm stopping playing this as of today and I may check back in a year or so to see if you have sorted out the steam version.

That being said the game has a lot of potential but the devs have to come to the conclusion that PC gamers are not mobile gamers.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is an iterative review
date:
reflecting nearly a year of interaction with 22Cans and attempts at playing Godus: Godus is boring; 22Cans has mislead its customers; Do Not Waste Your Time or Money. Continuing to sell Godus in Early Access, Valve hurts the Steam brand.

<edited to reflect The Roadmap>
Godus is a free-to-play mobile game that may -- emphasis on the uncertainty -- someday become a casual PC game that is optimized for tablets.

As of this review (June 2014), 22Cans has ignored customer and backer feedback for 1.5 years, or nearly nine months longer than they originally expected development to take. I am sure that ~some~ members of the community are happy with Godus. But the majority of feedback on Steam's forums, the vast majority of the reviews on this site, and everything I have heard about the backer forums" strongly indicates that people thing Godus is going in a bad direction
recommended:
and in a direction antithetical to the original intent the regenesis of the godgame.

PM has said that the primary goal of a game designer is to make money. One would have thought that the primary goal of a game designer who was crowdfunded would be to deliver the game that people thought they were funding (or to fail in the attempt.)

Over time
hoursPlayed: the game has incorporated more free to play (f2p) elements
voteText: such as gems
helpfulPercent: and stickers
votesHelpful: and wait timers
votesTotal: things that break a person's progression with the game and fundamentally destroy any chance of immersion. After each update
votesFunny: the community gave constructive feedback
commentsCount: suggested different mechanics that would improve our experience
column16: and attempted to engage 22Cans in the promised "participation in game design." 22Cans would go silent for weeks or months at a time
column17: and then make changes like "click and swipe" instead of "clicking" (when the fundamental concern was that this farmville-type mechanic was fundamentally broken and that a Player Deity should not have to concern itself with swiping and that it made no sense in-game.)\n\n22Cans has likely made these decisions at the behest of it's mobile publisher DeNA. A publisher
column18: mind you
column19: that they promised not to take on when they pitched their kickstarter.\n\nWith the release of the Roadmap
column20: 22Cans has confirmed that a) they will continue deceiving customers (they are using a SDK that builds software for multiple platforms concurrently
column21: and there is no difference between the mobile game and the PC game beyond the length of timers and the presence of a gem shop to speed up said timers) b) they have no interest in delivering a game that is not casual in nature
column22: and c) 22Cans will continue to ignore the feedback of the community that backed their vision and funded their company.\n\nFor the past several months
column23:
I have enjoyed interacting with other members of the Godus forums as we tried desperately to get 22Cans to deliver the game that they had promised. The Roadmap proves that our attempts were in vain. Don't give Peter more money to make a free to play game.
</edit>

<edited to reflect 2.01 & GDC comments>

Godus is a F2P mobile "zen-like" game. Think "Sim-Bulldozer" with a lovely ambient soundtrack and you will get a good sense of what to expect. Using a mouse or touchpad to interact with the game may lead to a repetitive stress injury and should be avoided at all costs.

The good: the artwork & the audio (both highly subjective)
The bad: gameplay mechanics (hour long timers to complete actions
column24: collection of "stickers" that break immersion
column25: etc.); strategy (gameplay is functionally on rails
column26: i.e. there is one "correct" way to play the game); feedback from devs (new community manager is doing a good job
column28:
P.M. strongly suggested that indie developers should ignore community EVEN WHEN they have explicitly promised community feedback will guide game development)
</edit>

Godus is not yet what I'd expect for a PC god game. As of 1.4
column29: it plays like a clicking-oriented mobile game where one shapes the land and creates space for automated followers to build structures. The structures are uniform across the first two ages (all that has been released): housing in age one
column30: farms in age 2.\n\nThe real tragedy of the game is that it was advertised as the successor to Black & White and Populous. These earlier games forced the player to choose between competing goals which would differentiate the play moving forward. B&W did a particularly good job incorporating moral alignment into all aspects of the game. Godus
column32: simply requires the player to click - a lot - and create flat land for development.\n\nOn a positive note
column33: the landscape (pre-farm) is pretty and I find the sound appealing.\n\nI will revisit this review once an update causes me to change my opinion."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When I was young games like Dungeon keeper and B&W started my pc gaming career, heck I even liked Fable dispite most of the claims Peter Molyneux not paning out. Chalk it up to a reverse bionic man, they just didn't have the tech. It was on that track record that I gave Godus an extra bit of patience.

The carrot on the stick that kept me coming back were the updates about how this new team that was left to work on this game after Peter moved on to other things. But those quickly turned into vague, nothing posts about nothing that did nothing to convince me that things were on the path to the better.

In the end, I would love to one day rewrite this review into a postive one about how a game that everyone assumed had died and was forgotten got a fabled miraculous combat patch update and this sceen saver simulator finally becomes something more then a title in my library I hope to one day trade to some innocent gamer who knows nothing about it. Anyways, if you see this game on sale I would say avoid it. They already got their kickstarter and Steam EA money, no sense padding their wallets anymore.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Generally, I support Alpha games/games in development. And with fond memories of Populous and Black & White I had no problem throwing some money to Peter Molyneux to finish his god-game. Now I find out he's not going to finish it. The game, per it's menu, is 53% complete and he's moved on to his next project. I think it's a sin that it's still up for sale and it certainly doesn't help support indie game development.

The game" as it stands is incredibly tedious and repetitive and
recommended: devoid of a plot line or story.\n\nJust walk away from this one."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I didn't think that a game by Peter Molyneux could possibly deserve the poor reviews, so when Humble had the game on sale, I bought it to see for myself.

How wrong I was.

There are so many reviews summing up the poor aspects of the game, but overall - for me - the one thing that sticks out most is the fact that the game was unceremoniously dumped onto the PC market in its mobile app form. With the exception of buying items for real world money, there appears to be no difference between the two versions of the game - no thought has been given to the difference of the platforms or the gamers.

Certainly, the game is early access, and who knows, may actually improve if pigs start flying. There are many early access games that are less developed (apparently Godus is currently 51% complete), cheaper and still far superior than this.

For the person who brought us Populous, Fable and Black & White, this is not a game to be proud of.

Certainly not worth the £14.99 current cost and not even worth the £4.89 I paid.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I can't really recommend this game. I supported this during the KS and played it through a number of the iterations. I've sunk over 30 hours into the game so far, so it's not like I didn't try to like it. Currently this game is more like Settlers or similar games to Settlers. It's not a Populous game, it's just your basic, grind-fest god game.

Some of the earlier iterations were really great and the game looked very promising but the devs changed the game greatly and now it's no longer a fun and enjoyable game. It's like everytime you get through a roadblock, there's another 3 roadblocks created. The game has forced paths and feels very limited and linear in so far as progression is concerned.

I simply can't recommend this game in its current form and the way the development has been going lately, I don't see that changing any time soon.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As I write this, the game has been taken back to the drawing board for a redesign due to the backlash from the community at the direction the game has gone. So this review may not reflect the finished product but reflects Ver 1.3.1

The game in it's current state is a click fest of a tablet game that has no depth or fun and not worthy of investment until a product is put forward that reflects the game as originally promised on kickstarter. The graphics are pleasant and has a familiar feel of previous titles from Peter Molyneux, but falls short on imagination and innovation with a population of hermits with no free will or character. If you accidentally click on one of the houses and a follower escapes captivity as I like to call it, they will eventually die if there is no shrine or building to work on, they will not re-house themselves and nor can you do that for them. A couple of hours in to this game, you come to care very little about their peril and and when you hear the famous Wilheim scream from the movies, you just shrug and carry on with your dragging and clicking.

I feel this game has taken a lot from the Curiosity experiment which was a tablet and smartphone app to see how people work together tapping away at a cube for an end result. I can't imagine anything more unfulfilling than clicking away at a screen with no strategy involved or end in sight for that matter. It just keeps going and going.

For those of use who have already bought in to the beta (and still care) we do hope to have an update which turns this around and gives us the God like feeling we have been hoping for and to have miracles that aren't just land sculpting and clicking houses. For those interested in the game, wait for the finished product or just read up on peoples feedback to each update on the forums.

At this stage, I really can't recommend this game even if someone has the spare cash and curiosity.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Buy it on discount and it will still be too much.
It seemed like a winner in the early stages of the game, and I was so excited to see it develop.

It's an excellent time waster but what you get for the time invested is beyond anti-climactic. Waiting to get a tiny piece of land uncovered for 15 hours instead of them just creating new worlds...
After the tutorial island you come to Weyworld. No instruction in how to use the severely underpowered defence archers, so you get wiped. Hardly any place to plant fields so expanding is soooo slow.
And then when Weyworld finally is finished.. there is nothing.

I sunk 170 hours into this, mostly in the background of films, since the game has to be open to unlock areas.

Up to you to buy it, but recommend it? No, can't do that.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

New review since I can now play the game, after about a month of having it constantly crash on me.

This game is not good. It tries to be too many things at once: a modern version of Populous, a game that is playable both on mobile and on PC, and a challenging yet easy game.

It succeeds at nothing. The game is too hand holding at first, and becomes incredibly obtuse later. It is riddled with remains of mobile tropes like 'gems' which have a half-arsed implementation on PC: you get them for 'free', but they are both needed and drop too little to be of actual use.

Only get his on a deep sale like it recently had (I picked it up for €4), at least until the developers manage to make it better.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Worth 15 bucks...  but barely...(as long as they stop trying to add paywalls and microtransactions like they tried to weasel in at one point... This isn't worth microtransactions, Peter thinks his game has more value than what reality dictates)....

For how long Godus has been developed, it seems VERY unfinished.... There is a LOT missing in order to call it a game... I think Peter bit off more than he is capable of swallowing... No rival AI worth a damn.... It's one sided... It gets old and boring fast without an adequate threat.... Populous was awesome and well designed... This could be like that game, but it's just not at the moment... Random raiding parties to fend off with a couple feeble god powers (more annoying than anything)... The archers (the only other defense) are worthless... There is no enemy rival God trying to raise, protect, and defend his own tribe(s)... The limited sculpting drag length gets annoying and tedious fast... I honestly hate having to manipulate land at all... It would be nice if buildings didn't need totally flat land to build on... Hillside building would be cool...

Build Build Build for no other reason but to get bigger and Build some more... I'm not ready to absolutely hate it, but if it doesn't go more in the populous direction with rival enemy AI, then this is just going to be garbage

There is beggining structure for a potentially awesome God Game here, but from what I've read, this company seems barely holding its head above water... i wouldn't evpect this thing resulting in anything great in the end

JUST MAKE A REALLY GREAT POPULOUS!!!!... Make an exact game as the original Populous with modern graphics and a little more added, like multi player, AND IT WOULD ROCK!!!.... Stop trying to get fancy and doing it as horribly as possible!!!! Populous was great.... this thing is NOT

Early Access Review

It's got an awesome design, visually speaking. It's very artsy — At least to me. I like the look. Sure it's not the latest & greatest graphically, but it's different, it's fun, and it's artistic. It feel appropriate for the type of game and the in game setting.

But the game is boring. Not because it's slow but because it's overly repetative. Morph the land to build more and to earn more followers and then expand more, oh look a piece of treasure, now expand more land... inch by inch I might add. I'ts mind numbing, it's boring, it's slow.

I don't honesly like leaving a bad review or a negative rating, let alone on a game that is still in Early Access, but it's just not there for me.

Early Access Review

The game is about landing on an island, levelling out and smashing houses together to form cities. but there is something mildly therapeutic about spend hours just making an area the same level. if u look at a 'successful' island. there is no character, no flow. i dont think the creators had an endgame in mind.

Original:

I bought this game expecting good things from Peter Molyneux, but there really isn’t any progress here.
I know I should have learned my lessons but this thing has been in beta for 2 years, and there really isn’t any progress. Actually it’s more like digress:

They have taken out key features which made this feel like a god game.
Now it just seems like a glorified Mobile game (actually I think they stretched their wings so far as to make a mobile version, which requires an additional cost)

Premise: flatten out land and remove trees so little people can build outs which u click on for exp, while avoiding infinite waves of bad guys trying to take your little people.

I'd like to push these guys to get out of early access but there is not point. After 2 years, they got their money. And they're laughing

reviewText:
Early Access Review

i was excited when i saw godus on steam, i bought it even though it was still in early access; the video i'd seen and the name attached to the game were large factors in that.
on first play i noticed right away that the feel of the game was for mobile and not for the pc. figured i could live with that, wth. well, turns out there were all sorts of obvious mechanics that were meant for micro-transactions, all to be implemented later on, which made the gameplay ridiculous on a pc. game turned frustrating pretty quick. i uninstalled it and let it sit for about a year before i returned hoping development had come further and my gripes had been solved.
i returned to find total silence from 22cans, a community stewing in anger, development seemingly come to a standstill, developers in the wind, and a game that was still frustrating. promises had been made! suggestions would be considered! all pretty much empty words.
then a ray of hope, new builds, and the silence from the devs is broken. except, the same thing happens again. at this point i'm just fed up. i know the game is in EA but the writing's pretty clearly on the wall. maybe i'll return again if it ever goes gold, but until then, it's a big disappointment. too bad to, i really enjoyed Dungeon Keeper and Fable.

Sorry to say, but even with latest updates this game remains utter crap. Considering how bad this is, and probably will remain when finished, it will never be worth the fortune that was required for early access. I for one wish i never paid a cent for this game.

So, good luck!

As for the review. If you like playing games with no meaningful progress what so ever, go for it! If you liked populus and want this game because it is similar to that game? take your computer and throw it out the window, get your shoes on, and go for a run. Because going for a run makes more sense then wasting your money on this game. So, if your wondering what makes this game bad? Well, for one, there is still nothing to do. You click around, and wait for the time to pass. Nothing grows, nothing progresses. Your sims do nothing, and achive nothing. You achive nothing and do nothing but clicking around. After a while you get a spell that enables you to set fire to trees. Guess what you do next? You are so bored that its 99% chance you set fire to the whole town you just spent hours building, because, thats the most action you ever gonna see in this game.

Beware, stay away, and remember: if your god is as boring as this one, change religion!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game itself has a lot of potential.  You're a god, you get to shape and morph the land around you and help an entire population grow and prosper.  However, as it currently stands, there are so many improvements needed, that one might quit playing after an hour of repetitive clicking and expanding, clicking and expanding, clicking, and, you guesed it, trying to expand.

The card resource system is flawed.  Once you can't find cards, you're out of luck for trying to upgrade any of your next improvements.  The game is currently only 40% unlocked, so I hope this issue is resolved with expansion and more multiplayer battles for cards. Either, or as someone else mentioned, a system in which resources can be mined or harvested.

My finger goes numb from all the clicking.  Every house your citizens build accumulates more influence, the main source of your power in the game.  After a while, if you want to collect influence, you have to go back and individually click every house that has available influence to give to you.  I really wish there was some sort of collect all" option
hoursPlayed: This game has some serious flaws that ruin the enjoyability of the game pretty quickly.  I don't know why I put as many hours into it as I did.  Hopefully
voteText: the game improves

As of 9 AUG 14.  Do not purchase this game.  I've come back to Godus several times hoping it would end up like Black & White since Peter Molyneux is the driving force.  Since it's foundation Godus has played more like a browser game you come back to daily than a PC game.  Now with the launch of Godus Mobile the true market has been revealed.  I do not understand why they spent so much time developing it for PC when this is very clearly a game designed for mobiles.

Gameplay mechanics consist of shaping the world with clicking, and waiting for your followers to breed or generate belief.  If you love clicking and waiting purchase this game.  If you are expecting something like Black & White or Black & White 2, go elsewhere.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Neither the video, screenshots nor description on the store page, accurately conveys the current state of Godus.

In development for close to 18 months now, the PC/Mac version of the game actually reached it's peak in September 2013. Since then, development has focused on making the game 'mobile friendly'.
This has unfortunately resulted in the game becoming progressively less like a God game, to the point we are now at, where the game actually has more in common with Farmville than Populous, Black&White or Powermonger.

Some of the more detestable features include, Waiting 40+ minutes for a house to be built and populated, endless sticker collection to try and unlock marginal improvements in the game, Players being forced to farm wheat once they reach a population cap which then all but stops game progress, using expansion shrines instead of an area of influence mechanic, forcing players along a set path instead of allowing them to explore the open" world

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After giving this game almost an entire year of time to change my mind, I'm finally writing a review.

Around last Christmas time I found this game, and I looked into it, and read about what it was supposed to be like. Considering that I'm a huge fan of Minecraft, this seemed like a really wonderful game that would offer similar mechanics and a beautiful art style. It also boasted that it wasn't yet complete, and that tons of other features would be added.

Throughout my time playing Godus, i quickly realized that it wasn't what was promised. There are many, many things that are disappointing, frustrating, and down right infuriating. The worst part is that when I redownloaded it recently, I expected that some of these basic things would be improved upon. They haven't been. Based on that, I'm writing this review.

The worst and most disappointing thing is that this game truly became a mobile 'waiting' game. It works with the same mechanics as Farmville, but the in-game mechanics and balancing of certain features are worse. When I purchased the game initially I thought that it wouldn't be like this at all. It really cheapens the idea of what could have been an amazing game.

My biggest beef is that within the year that I didn't play it, I came back to the game being more buggy, having worse balance issues, and being more laggy on my system for no reason. I kept having the repeated issue of cards not appearing when I completed an objective, or the finger of god not working properly. The spacing of buildings has obviously been changed from what I remember, it is no longer as intuitive and everything is poorly spaced. Every UI aspect has gotten more and more annoying, like if I have a new card, the pulsating of the top right button is aggrivating. The way that the stickers have been rebalanced seems way, way worse. There is now one, maybe two stickers in every treasure box, whereas a year ago it was more randomized and you could find between 1-5 stickers in a box. They are almost forcing you to used the voyage function, however that hasn't been upgraded or improved since last year either. They've made it increasingly challenging to get stickers and gems in the worst way, because it now feels like sculpting to find treasure boxes isn't worth the belief, and the voyages only yield a small amount of a specific sticker at every goal reached. Honestly that alone was so annoying that I just stopped improving any card that I didn't think was necessary- and in doing that it appeared that new cards weren't appearing anymore when I completed a goal.

My final, most infuriating issue with this game is the Astari aspect. Nothing is explained well enough, their appearance in the game isn't explained enough, and the way that their mechanic works makes no sense. You basically have to rely on the finger of god power, and once you've done that, there is absolutely no point in creating or pushing for the military settlements. Since the Astari and the reason that they are in the game is never explained, they feel like a giant annoyance that continually pesters you. The fact that the only real option is to wipe them out by saving up belief and then either squishing them during their festival or squishing a tree and then squishing them in rounds of 4-5 feels both annoying and cheap. They also somehow gain happiness at an inhumane level, which makes it incredibly challenging to not eradicate them immediately so that you just don't have to deal with them any more.

Apparently the one thing that has been entirely reworked is the fighting mechanics, which I didn't even have a chance to see. Between cards that I remember being there a year ago being removed, the gem system being ridiculously unbalanced (considering that now basically your only option to progess in cards is to gain gems to buy packs, instead of it being about the finding of treasure or even the voyages), and how the sculpting is still the most tedious and uninuitive feature in the game... I'm uninstalling, I'm never reinstalling. I'm thankful that I bought this game on sale for $5, but even that doesn't feel worth the money at this point.

My advice to the developers? Drop the project. You released this game 2 years ago and have made no improvements for at least a year. Try not to screw up this hard next time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Don't bother with this pile of garbage. Peter Molyneux is a known overhyper and swindler. I paid $20 for this a year and a half ago and its the same pile of unfun micro management garbage that offers absolutely nothing new to the god game genre. And its just kills me to look at the same terrible ui and visuals that have plagued this game since its inception. The developers have abandoned ship and Molyneux is too busy with the mobile version. I could have invested that $20 in far better indie games. MULTIPLE far better indie games.

Who at 22Cans studios thought that the NEXT EVOLUTION of God games would be:

*Continuously deform terrain for hours so that there is FLAT space where you can build houses.
*Click your current houses so that your followers will go out and build houses on flat spaces, increasing population.
*Continue to deform terrain so you can discover 'cards' that let you research new things.
*Rinse, repeat, until you've unlocked all research, and rinse, repeat until your 'Civilization' looks a Rio De Janeiro ghetto that spans the entire world, is filled with huts on one side where you started, and manor houses on the other where your technology has advanced. Then realize the entire time you've been playing a glorified mobile time waster game where you wait for your houses to reach a certain time, then click on them to collect 'god power'. Then, wait until they're ready to be HARVESTED again, and click it again! OH BOY, SO MUCH FUN. I'M DYING FROM THE FUN. IT'S LIKE A PC VERSION OF FARMVILLE.

HONESTLY, Black & White 2 was far more fun than this pile of garbage. Why didn't Molyneux decide to make a Black & White 3, and fulfil all the hyped up promises and features that he NEVER put in Black & White 2?

Why Peter Molyneux or anyone at 22Cans could possibly think from the beginning that this monotonous, personality-less gameplay they developed could EVER turn into anything marginally fun to play is BEYOND me.

Terrible from inception, and with the way the games structured now, theres no way it could ever be fun.

I want my $20 back, but I know that'll never happen. And lets be clear here, I didn't buy this a month ago and now I'm freaking over the fact that the game hasn't changed entirely in a month. I BOUGHT IT ONE AND A HALF YEARS AGO.

2/10
Fun for the first 20 minutes.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game starts off good, but rapidly degrades as you advance. The problem is that there are multiple resources required for building, sculpting landscape, gaining and using skills and powers, and all of these resources are on very long timers.

A slightly different version of Godus is available on iOS, where this Zynga-esque wait-for-resources, pay-to-play type of system is very common. On moble, it's a little more tolerable. Many people don't mind playing in short bursts when they have a few spare minutes in their day. Even there, it's widely regarded as poor design that puts profits over players.

For a PC game, however, people tend to sit down with the intent to play for a while. Having the game tell you you have to wait 20 minutes for resources, only to burn through those resources in a minute or two, is not good design. The PC version doesn't have the microtransactions, so waiting is the only option, even for the obscenely rich.

It's unfortunate, because there are some fun elements here. But they're totally overshadowed by the glaring problems. I'd like to think that they'll be addressed as development continues, but I'm not so sure. Neither the built-in developer commentary nor the developer responses on the forums acknowledge these major issues or offer any solutions to address them.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In its current state, Godus is a chore more than a game. You click, click, click until your hand gets numb, with little to reward you other than more things to click on.  Everything feels like it is designed not to entertain you, but to keep you busy. There is progression, but only in a sense that things start off tedious, and then you are given tools to make your gameplay slightly less tedious.

You start off having to click on each individual house to gather belief, with which you can sculpt land. If there was some moderation to this it would be alright, but it literally takes hours to get anywhere and your wrist will start hurting from the hundreds of times per minute you have to click to get a decent patch of land for your villagers to settle on. Then you are given some new tools through which you can do more while clicking less, which does make the game less tedious, but with a focus on the word less - and there still isn't anything that actually entertains. It would help if your villagers seemed to have lives of their own, but even on that front not much seems to happen. They just stay in their houses until you decide they are allowed to come out - then, when there is no place for them to settle, they just die.

I would advice people who are on the fence about this game to first watch some movie reviews before purchasing this game, as there are quite a number of decent reviews out there that pinpoint exactly where this train went off the rails.

The game is surviving on Peters name, and that is it. This is not worthy of a single penny much less the $19 they are asking for now, or whatever the cost is now. Let me make it short and sweet.

- If you like doing mundane tasks, for no reward at all. Then pick up this game.
- If you do not have high expectations and do not care if you are let down, and have money to waste. Pick up this game.
- If you feel you have been neglecting your mouses buttons lately, and feel it needs a work out. Get this game.
- If you are trying to wear out your mouse, so you can convince your parents, wife, girlfriend, etc. To get a new one. Get this game.
- If you are expecting a game like Populous. Avoid this game like the plague. The only thing similar is the followers and that is even pushing it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

EDIT 28 March 2014: The developer is now more communicative with their players and has released a major update to the game. The game is overall much less of a chore to play now but it's still based on social game conventions, in other words, most of the gameplay consist of waiting for real world hours to recharge belief, build shrines or refilling a boat embark on voyages (missions that play like a simplified version of Lemmings). The gameplay additions are welcome, but unfortunately the number of bugs and crashes of the game has increased. I would recommend to wait a little more until the game is more complete and polished before spending 18,99€ on it.

I know that when you buy an Early Access / in-development game you can't expect it to contain most of the promised features at first, but at least I expect regular communication from the developers (weekly or even monthly updates about its development). There hasn't been any announcement on the Steam Community since October, and their Facebook and Twitter feeds appear more interested in selling t-shirts than talking about the game.  I'm not asking for a big content update patch every week, but at least they should inform us about what they are working on (and I'm referring to what is being worked on for the 1.4 patch for example, not just cryptic we are working hard on your feedback and have big ideas for the future" kind of videos that just make more far-off promises). I feel like they have no pressure whatsoever in finishing the game
date: as they have my money already."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This text may be a little bit longer, so here is my conclusion up front: See this as a warning:
This is not a game, it‘s also not a „Zen-Like“ experience. It‘s another Mobile/F2P cash-grab waiting to happen. I haven‘t seen anything this brash since the Dungeon Keeper Mobile „game“.  As a Kickstarter-Backer I feel betrayed by Molyneux and 22Cans and the only reason I checked the latest update (2.1) was out of morbid curiosity.
It just sucks, don‘t buy it! If you are really curious, just wait for professional reviews to tear this thing apart. Or look at all the other negative reviews here. Many of the more realistic people have abandoned this F2P garbage long ago, just search the forums for a bit, or check the Kickstarter comments: https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/22cans/project-godus/comments
However: Most reviews are still negative, and with good reason:

Maybe I should start with the only positive thing I have to say about Godus: There are so many timers that I can go off and do pretty much anything else, until they finally run out. I‘m not kidding: I played through the Expendrabros campaign and I still had to wait another 10 minutes until anything happened in this „game“.

Even simple buildings take up to 30 minutes to build, depending on their size. Well, you could say: Isn‘t there an upgrade that accelerates building time by 90%?
Yes, there is, but now you need wheat to build new houses. First of all you need a farming settlement to get farmers, which costs 3000 belief, which, at this point of the game, takes more than one hour to gather.
Now there are another 30 minutes until you can send out the first farmer, who needs 90 to 120 minutes to give you 2 – 4 wheat, depending on the size of the field.
The next building you unlock after gaining the ability to create farms takes 30 minutes again and needs 6 wheat, so yay, even more timers.
Later on you get mining settlements, which cost 7500 belief, which is not so bad at this point. Just gather the belief you can get right now, shut Godus down, play Sins of a Solar Empire Rebellion for a hour or two, check into Godus again, gather belief, and so on. It should only take about 5 hours. Miners now take one hour to spawn und the mines take 6 hours to give you anything.
Oh, and you only get belief after a timer runs out, small buildings take about 20 minutes, settlements about 5 hours.
(and that‘s also the reason some people have so many hours of Godus on their steam account: it‘s something you just have running in the background. It‘s NOT actual gameplay)

But there is a solution for this problem: Gems!
You can use gems to finish any timer. You can „earn“ some gems by voyages (about 29 in total, which is a joke) or you sacrifice some of your followers. That wouldn‘t be so bad, because the little guys and gals don‘t have any personality whatsoever, if the game wouldn‘t try to make you feel bad about it (which doesn‘t bother me either). And then the „game“ suddenly starts to punish you badly for unhappy followers without warning. Everything else get‘s a unskippable tutorial, except the happiness „system“, so it come‘s really unexpected in an otherwise astonishing linear „game“.

You see: Followers become unhappy, if you send them to their doom, what you will want to do, so you don‘t have to wait for hours until you are able to do anything again. It doesn‘t have any impact on their behaviour, so nothing is lost here, but there is one problem: There is another tribe, the Astari, who don‘t really do anything, no expanding, nothing (there is no AI to speak of, so far, and I don‘t think there will ever be any). They aren‘t even on the same island as you and all they do at the beginning is mock your people, so they want build so fast. Not really a threat.
But: When your people are not as happy as the Astari, they leave you periodically, and you can do nothing to stop them. A lot of people will leave you (the first time this happened to me, I lost 125 of about 400 people). So not only do you have to start the whole process of waiting all over again, you also have to get your people happy.

Either you use some simple miracles and spend a lot of believe (thousends of it), which will take you forever, or you spend some gems on fountains and special trees. It‘s kinda like Fable III: They have no personality, they just react to stuff, which has some consequences and otherwise they only have some idle animations (I checked Fable III out after becoming disappointed about Godus, and I would have never ever backed it, if I had known what a trainwreck Fable turned out to be). They do nothing else: They don‘t build on their own, no exploration. It‘s all micro-managing.

Basicly: Every aspect of this game screams cashshop, like in the free Mobile version. If you ever read Molyneuxs reaction to Dungeon Keeper Mobile, than you might find it funny that you can spend 70$ for gems in the shop.
Right now you can‘t guy any gems for real money in the „PC version“ and 22Cans keep reassuring us, that this won‘t ever be possible on PC, but frankly, after almost two years of misdirection (just check the Kickstarter page), broken promises (weekly updates) and just straight up lies (for example the FAQ of the Kickstarter page), I see no reasons to trust those people anymore.
In my opinion they are designing the whole game to be absolutly tedious without the use of gems, just so they can get in the cashshop with the argument, that we asked for it.

The controls are awful with mouse and keyboard, the sculpting is imprecise and the graphics are just horrible, especially the animations, when zoomed out just a little bit. They even got worse since the Mobile launch. There isn‘t even a free rotating camera. They have been focusing on Mobile for the last two years, and it shows.

While checking through some other Steam reviews I saw one that said „This game comes along nicely“, and I have to disagree! Godus has been in development for almost two years now (December 2012) and for almost one in Early Access (September 2013). In one year, they added the happiness system, and almost nothing else. There have been minor things, like having to grind wheat and ore in addition to the believe, but mostly it‘s only a variation of the stuff there already is. Oh, and there were the voyages, the only thing reminding me of a real game, simply because it‘s a cheap Lemmings knockoff. The „game“ has even lost more features than it gained. There are no multiplayer skirmishes anymore, and there is no „campaign“. While both were awfull, they at least had potential.

Apart from that, there really isn‘t much to say about the game itself, because there really isn‘t much. It is awfully linear. You grind three kinds of things (people, farms and mines) to get new abilities and bonuses. It‘s just another Mobile/F2P game.

In comparison: The majority of the Steam community and the Kickstarter backers told 22Cans that they don‘t want any timers and especially no gems, and just look how that turned out. Molyneux is really great at nullifying the critics: The Steam community doesn‘t matter, because it doesn‘t understand the concept of Early access. The Kickstarter Backers don‘t matter, because basicly he just wanted to get the reinvention of the god game financed, but Kickstarter forced him to write all those promises and stuff. I am really, really sick of it. yourself: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KoHG3buq5xM

I really have no hope for this game, whatsoever. Just stay away from it, or wait for some final verdicts by game journalists, if you really have to. Personally, I will never buy anything for 22Cans again and I am looking forward for the inevitable failure of Godus and hopefully of the studio behind it.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nStill an incredibly slow game.  It feels like Farm Ville" or "The simpsons" Ipad app's. reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nBack in the distant Eighties, Peter Molyneux created the first 'god game' POPULOUS. An early milestone in personal gaming. Simple but instructive UI, a logical and addictive mechanic, challenging progression and a true sense of achievement when a game was won. Nowadays, we are presented with monetisation: in-game purchases, carrot & stick condescension; a dumbed-down, craven ideology - tantalising to look at but utterly devoid of fun - the essential ingredient of a 'good game'. I want a story about humanity's impact on the world, a wise fable about the consequences of unfettered exploitation, the threat of climate change - prehistoric as well as contemporary. An archaeological story rich with detail, humour and frivolity. What happened to you Peter???

I followed the Kickstarter progress with great anticipation.  When the first version came out, I played it for a while.  It was very rough around the edges, but it had potential.  Now it's 3 or more major iterations later, and things have actually gotten worse.  Your people are either very stupid, or try to kill themselves on purpose.  The land sculpting was fun in the beginning, but has gotten so epensive now, it's not worth the trouble.

And then there is the waiting...  If you like free to play crap where you have to wait 30 minutes for a house to be built (or give us some gems and you get it instantly) then you will LOVE this game.  But it has no place in a PC environment.  PC games tends to sit down for an hour or more gaming session, not a 5 minute click on everything and queue it all up so you can wait again tomorrow."  And even though the PC version of Godus has no method to buy gems for cash
date: it still is the same mentality.\n\nI am very disappointed.  The only bright side I can see is that the game is currently 50.5% complete.  Hopefully they can still bring this game back."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Yeah, this is my first review, so it'll probably be awful, but I'm going to be brutally honest here: This waste of cash was BORING.

What do I mean?  Well...there is so much micromanaging, but that's only percentage-wise.  The gameplay is EXTREMELY slow, enough to put someone to sleep.  A game about being a sky-god SHOULD NOT BE BORING.  I spent the entire first session, all 91 minutes or whatever, waiting for it to kick up its intensity even slightly.

Nothing.  Black and White was better than this - B&W shoots Godus with a sniper rifle, in one eye and out the other, from a distance of about a kilometer, then does awful things to its corpse.

To make it worse, the click-and-drag interface.  Oh.  Dear. GOD the interface.  A lot of people seem to be frustrated by this point, so read those reviews for more details.

I would more easily recommend Dwarf Fortress - yes, THAT Dwarf Fortress - to a casual gamer, than I would this to anyone.  Heck, I enjoy DF, and I'm pretty casual.

That this game is $20 USD isn't just salt in the wound.  It's more like someone put a rocksalt shot in a shotgun, put the barrel's opening directly on my right hand, and pulled the trigger.  I literally would not recommend this game for 10% of its asking price.

You want a better game?  Go buy Dragon: the Game.  It's $2 cheaper than this, and while yes, it's still in development and pretty buggy, that means the developers want your input as much as your cash.  Give it to them, and don't give this developer a dime.

You want another better game?  How about The Long Dark.  Same price, but much better developed, with survival in the wilds of frozen Canada and wolves trying to tear you to pieces.  It's tough, but at least it's a way better buy.

You want another one?  What am I, a computer?  Go browse on your own.  You'll probably find more hits on Steam than this thing's cost in pennies.

recommended: there's less clicking (more click+dragging) but it's pretty much the same game

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Right now, this is not fun at all.

It's painfully obvious how they made this a mobile centric game, and their (to me) annoying slathering of time delay mechanics infuriates me.


In my opinion, time delays and and cool downs have to be the laziest game design mechanic i have ever had the displeasure of experiencing. Especially when they are needlessly added to a game to artifically extend the total play time of the game. And even more so when the intention is to hook the player so they feel the need to come back to the game after the hour long wait is over. That is a trope used by mobile games since their genesis. I do not find it fun, and Godus is filled to the brim with it.

There is some potential for a great experience in this however. Unfortunatly it is burried under a mountain of problems:
waiting around for things to snowball (if that ever happens).

horrible pathfinding AI the followers exhibit.

not being able to destroy old buildings to alow for newer better abodes.

painfully slow progression (i want to be able to get reasonably far in an 2 hour play session).

Voyages are not fun at all for me, i want to manage my homeworld. That's why im playing a god game. I don't want to do silly mini games meant for mobile players to gain the very basic tools to progress in the main game. Also bogged down by the crap pathfinding and clunky inconsistent sculping.

The gathering rate of belief is to low, almost all my time is spent waiting or grinding in voyages to get belief just so i CAN PLAY THE MAIN GAME THAT I PAYED FOR !
If these things are fixed/balanced or removed I believe i would indeed enjoy the game, because watching the followers grow, your towns grow, and your landscape grow, is all extremely cool and fun. For the PC version at least. PLEASE.

Please note: theres the entire back half and end game i have not yet experienced since i can not will myself to play the game that long.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The description of this game by the developers is 'zen like' and at points there is certainly a meditative quality to it, but ultimately this is an inaccurate claim.

The calm nature of meditation is ultimately shattered by frustration, and this game has it in spades. Want your 'zen' crushed by a bunch of dudes burning down your village from outside the range of your sphere of influence? Play this game. Want important things left unexplained (like the fact you can't build mines just anywhere in the second world) until it is too late and then you are left in a monotonous grind? Play this game.

I really perservered at it, as it still had moments of enjoyement, but at the moment the experience is too frustrating for me to recommend it.

Positives:

-Developer commentary in game was interesting
-visuals weren't too taxing, suited the casual nature of a game like this, good to play on a laptop


Negatives
-invincible enemies hovering beyond your sphere of influence destroying your stuff
-bad port from tablet meaning most of the game is a horrible grind without the ability to buy your way out
-sculpting is far more frustrating and time consuming than it should be.
-there is no joy to wrestling with a UI rather than game mechanics and this defines things like placement of settlements.
-still a lot of bugs but that is something expected in a game still in development.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

*** This is NOT a Game ***  This is not a game no matter how you define the word. This is not a series of meaningful choices. This is not an immersive experience. This is not a set of practicable skills that build to a goal state. If anything it is basically a proof of concept to a publisher for a possible way to monetize a mobile game - nothing more. To call this a game is a spit in the face to anyone who engages in the art.

This game" consists of basically four things. Clicking->dragging to flatten land. Clicking to make followers build things. Dragging to collect belief. Clicking->dragging to make individual followers move somewhere. Your followers have no will of their own and unless you command them to do something will just sit there idly forevermore. When you build a building it takes 8 to 30+ minutes of real time to build! These get shorter as the game progresses but the whole exercise is pointless irregardless. Your rewards just let you repeat the cycle of the above 4 actions more quickly and efficiently but the lack of any real goal or immersion remains. This is a 'game' to teach your 6 year old how to use a mouse. You could emulate this game in Microsoft Paint if you drew a square
date: copy and pasted it somewhere else
recommended:
and then waited 18 minutes before being able to do it again.

The microtransaction portion of this game comes in the form of gems. They try to stress how great gems were in the design process but anyone with half a brain see they serve absolutely no 'gaming' purpose in the game except to annoy and stall. This is a pay to win or pay to play game for mobile. Unless you pay building anything takes hours of real time in which case your paying opponents will have a city 10 times your size and will mop the floor with your face. They try to stress in the PC version that you will never pay for gems because you've paid for the game. True but they will make you grind for the gems with a really bad thing called 'voyages' which are basically really simplified annoying lemmings minigames where you just sculpt land to make your followers follow certain paths before a time limit ends. The voyage games are something out of a first project for an intro class for computer gaming in terms of concept. Tic Tac Toe has more strategic depth than the voyage minigames imo.

--- This is the first game I've played in which I would've preferred doing nothing. --- It is just so pointless and dull and grindy from the very first minute of gameplay. The game's fundamental actions do not change after the first 3 minutes of the game. - Once you've waded thru the first few minutes and built your first house you've played the entirety of what this game has to offer. - The blatant monetizing of this game is sickening as well. In the PC version when you're out of belief or out of stickers to upgrade your abilities an annoying 'booster pack' of offers pops up on the bottom right of your screen and flashes with an annoying "buy me now!" noise. Given the monotony of the PC minigames I almost with there was an option to buy gems - that's how bad they are. The PC minigames were ONLY put in to avoid any sort of litigation stating their PC game is pay to win.

Final Verdict: Irrecoverable for eternity into anything resembling a game. No patches and design rehashes are going to fix this. The only redemption for this game is if they scrapped it entirely and kickstarted a new project from scratch. Mod's and Steam Workshop won't help this piece of junk either as there is nothing to mod. A Game creation Jam could probably replicate the core concepts of this game in a single 6 hour session. My only hope is this game is Peter's greatest troll ever and after a couple years his team releases the 'secret' game they've been working on all along and this entire project was a grand social experiment into human trolling.

Overall value for the money: This would be a bad buy for 99 cents at the app store when you're waiting for the subway to come in and want something to click and drag for a minute before leaving to queue up another 19 hours worth of tasks for your followers."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is awful, time spent in the game feels like time fully wasted. It reminds me of my mortality and makes me sad that I'm spending my precious time on this earth playing this crap. And I've played it for less than 10 hours since I bought it long ago.

It takes a certain type of s*** to cause that sort of hatred so quickly. And the worst thing is, that this game could have been sooooooooo ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ good. If not for the crap decisions the developers have made.


I'm not just going to ramble on about all the reasons this game is terrible (but it is, don't buy the game). Instead, I'll give you a first hand experience of my thoughts on this game, from the time I bought it till now.

I bought it far before the big 2.0 update (or should I say the entire scrapping and remaking of this game).
That's right folks, I was there at the very beginning of this disaster. I bought this game as it mentioned it was inspired by populous, and I thought 'wow, a game inspired by Peter Molyneux's good era of games, before he became an awful game developer, and without any input by him, sounds great!'

So I bought the game, and was excited at first, it wasn't bad initially, for the first 20 minutes. And then the awful AI multiplayer tutorials came on. Cringeworthy, embarrasing, pathetic. Playing with fake people, all of them tragic and worthy of some form of pity for some reason. One girl seemed to have issues with her dad, one dude was 30 and unemployed, desperate to gain fulfillment in his bleak life by getting more gems in the game.
And they never ended, they went on and on and on, this pathetic illusion of multiplayer. 'Why is the game doing this? Who thought it was a good idea? Why would they make it like this? Is this the only multiplayer in the game? Will it ever end?'
And then the grinding happened, which I should point out has not changed in the updates, it seems even worse now.

It was at this point that I found out that good old Peter Molyneux IS involved in the game, which explains so much. He was brilliant in his time, and I have huge respect for his older games. Black and White was a masterpiece, simple as. I've loved it for years, still play it occassionally, and I firmly believe that the creature AI is yet to be outdone in a game, including it's not so good sequel.
But now, Peter is the worst kind of 'maverick'. His ideas are great, but the way he implements them are terrible, TERRIBLE! And the reason is simple, there is nobody to reign him in. He is a well known figure, who's going to argue with him? They let him do what he likes, and he ♥♥♥♥s ♥♥♥♥ up.

If they took his great ideas, and then made them fun and enjoyable with some outside help, controlled him a bit, this game would have been fantastic. But it's not, it's garbage. It has been for a looooooong time, and the countless updates have done nothing to change that.

The only thing that could save it would be a complete overhaul of the game, redo it from scratch, remove the grinding, make it fun. But they won't do that, they can't, too much time has been spent on it already.

I'd demand a refund if I felt there was any hope of getting it. But to be honest, it was worth buying it for the multiplayer tutorials in the past. I'm serious, they were so awkward, so awful, it was hilarious, if slightly painful to read. The type of bad that only Peter Molyneux could make.


In short, don't buy this game, it's a great concept, could have been FANTASTIC, but is boring, dull, and tedious.

And the worst part is, the developers f***ing know it! They have the nerve to tell you in the commentary to do other things while you wait for crap to happen.
Do other things Peter eh? Like play another game? A good game? No need to tell me twice!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Godus is a game built without drama or conflict.  The only constraint you will run into is a risk of carpel tunnel as you slowly expand your influence in a dead world.  While Godus is technically a god game your followers cannot engage in any independent activity and require no food or resources to continue existing, as such there is nothing to do but keep nudging them to expand until a population cap is reached, and no constraint other than time to prevent you from reaching said cap.

It is also worth noting that while Godus states that followers are your measure of size and scope, followers do not directly create each other.  Followers instead make houses, and upon making a house they enter it and never again exit.  After a certain amount of time passes you can click on a house and get a new follower from it, and thus continue to expand your empire to houses.

Godus also features the ability to reshape the terrain.  While this can be fun, it lacks the visceral feel of performing the same action in a game like Minecraft and uses an interface for this that is less engaging than the one found in the original Magic Carpet.  Rather than using dramatic spells or a slow change from a low level by means of follower activity Godus chooses to have you raise and lower the terrain by means of double clicking.  I kickstarted this game, and unfortunately it did not deliver.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The recent (2.0) improvements to Godus are superficial at best and the new tutorial insulting.

I think one of the most fundamental problems is that there is no personality to your followers or their settlement. I would gladly collect belief and look for stickers if it actually meant that it created something spectacular and I could follow individual followers and their struggles to build families etc, to survive and build a civilization in a hostile world.

As it is all you're doing is creating space for them to build, but no reason for them to build something specific at a specific place. No dangers for them to overcome or strategy in placement or deliberate pacing. No economy except belief which is best acquired by not playing but rather logging out and returning later.

In Godus I am not a God, I am the creator of flat surfaces. I'm basically a bulldozer that collects stickers.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Reviewing GODUS as is at this time is not an option, the new build has mostly revised the rules around the game and thus invalidated a lot of the issues and complaints I would have listed. However, instead, I'm going to review the development narrative behind GODUS. Specifically, I'm going to look at Peter Molyneux's approach to developing games.

Molyneux reminds me of a child who's managed to find himself in a factory full of paint cans and brushes. Every colour is available to him, every possible brush thickness and shape, he wanders through the factory, his mouth open in a permanent expression of amused shock, his fingers delicately stroking the paintbrushes, his eyes full of childlike wonder. His imagination explodes, runs riot, he dreams of wonderful fantastic vistas, much like a child's imagination unchecked is capable of roaming so free and so far. However, like a lot of children, his imagination far exceeds his fine motor skills, so when it comes to taking the brush and applying paint to canvas...

... we get a splotchy mess.

GODUS is a splotchy mess. Fable was a splotchy mess. Most games that Molyneux has been involved in have been to some extent, a splotchy mess. The successes have come about when the rest of the team have been able to refine the splotchy messes and turn them into something that resembles what is actually either going on in Molyneux's head, or a marketable game, or somewhere between the two. It's tricky to figure out where the magic is, when it hits, like Black and White, it opens up whole new ways of looking at games in general, but unfortunately, you wind up seeing a lot of splotchy messes between the rare flashes of inspiration.

Not that it stops him. Now this would be perfectly human and forgivable were it not for the fact that Peter has a ... well, an almost Steve Jobs like Reality Distortion Field" that he projects. It's as if there are two different worlds in existence at any one time when Peter talks about his games

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A man cannot serve two masters.  Godus as it stands has too much tablet DNA to be a decent PC game.  This is a real shame, as there are some wonderful concepts there that can't quite get out.

I've like Peter Molyneux games since the beginning.  Godus is similar to Black and White in that the interaction with the world is very different to a standard PC strategy game.  This isn't a bad thing.  The lack of direct control, the interaction with the landscape, even the treasure hunt aspects are all really interesting and work well together.  But the problem lies in the execution.  It is very difficult to play this game for more than 15-20 minutes without running out of things to do.  On a mobile game, that's fine.  For a PC game, it's frustrating.  The reason for this is that everything is based on real world time, so if a beacon is going to take 16 hours to build, you shut the game down and come back in 16 hours.  Again, this is standard for a mobile game, and there are justifications for it in a social game as well I guess, but it means there is a lot of dead time.  Much more dead time than actual fun time.

The shame is, I enjoy playing the game.  The land sculpting and bringing together settlements is really well done and a lot of fun.  But normally after 5 minutes, just when I'm getting into it, I'm out of belief.  Then there's 5 minutes of hunting chests, maybe go on a voyage, but really there's nothing to do but close the program and wait a couple of hours.

As I say, the land scuplting aspect, coupled with the lovely minimalist artwork, really is lovely and interesting.  The landscape is beautiful, although it's something of a shame that your main interaction with it is to turn it into a flat parking lot to put houses up.  There is promise here, I will continue playing.  But at the moment I could not recommend this to anyone else.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a freemium game for the ios and android but is being charged a fee to play it on the pc. Well... I should clarify that. they removed the ability to buy stuff from the pc game but they left all of the stuff in there that is designed to slow down the game so that you buy stuff. very strange.... for example... I'm now waiting a few hours for some stuff to build.

This is the only game where I am glad to be interrupted while playing it because that means something will be done when I come back to the game.

Hopefully they remove all the painful delays from the game when it leaves early access.

Update: Ok. I've had some time to play the game and I'm now able to look beyond my overwhelming frustration with the time delay to provide some more feedback. (sort of able to look past it)

Pros:

1. I really like the look of the game
2. I also like how they let you model the land to build stuff on it. I think they got that one down pretty good.
3. I like how you have to grown your population to unlock stuff

Cons:
1. I HATE HATE HATE HATE HATE HATE having to wait 3 days for something to be built. And that is what the timer says. 3 days. it actually takes even longer then that because your workers take naps. So it will probably be 4 or 5 days. I'm going to do a few minor things in the game then I don't expect to ever play it again unless there are some radical changes in the wait time.
2. I hate all of the stupid, pointless resources. you have belief which lets you build some stuff. Then you have to get wheat to build other stuff and then you have to get ore to build other stuff and then you have to have gems to do other things. So you end up having to create this huge infrastructure of ore to be able to unlock to portals and once they are unlocked they don't do anything.
3. This game wins for being the most frustrating game I have ever played.
4. So there is this In-Game game where you have to get your followers to go from one point to another point on a map. It makes me so mad because you can't control your followers and they are idiots. Oh and did I tell you it is timed. So you have to get your followers to go from point a to point b in a very short time frame with no control over them and things are trying to kill them and you have limited resources. Fun... it is not.
5. Oh yeah. so my theory that they took the free game from the ios and brought it to the pc was confirmed. They forgot to remove a button from the pc version which, when you click on it, tells you to buy gems at the store... except for the pc version doesn't have a store so... yeah...


Conclusion: If they got rid of the wait times and balanced out the other stuff I think I could recommend this game... right now where the game is there is no way I would ever recommend it.

Oh yeah my hours into this game are so big because I just leave it running in the background. It is a easy way to build up resources.

Update 2:

Ok They just released a new balance option which is AWESOME. It lets you eliminate a majority of the stupid timers so that the game is actually fun. So here is the deal.

I would actually recommend this game if the balance options, which allow you to speed up the timers, stay in the game. However, I'm under the impression that they are going to remove them once the game gets more developed. At that point I think the game will go from being awesome to sucking.

I actually came into this review specifically to update my review to be a recommend when, as I was typing, I realized that they probably are going to remove the balance options and then I'd have to update my review again. I'm just going to leave it as a not recommend until I get more concrete info that the stupid timers are going to stay in seconds rather then days.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Godus, so far below par.

Having played the game on and off for the last few days, and currently at about the 12 hour mark of playtime, I can tell you that the game has a lot of potential.

A lot of the 'early' parts of the game are fleshed out well, and seem quite polished, however the 'middle' part of the game is about expansion and landscaping two things that are not very exciting, and often I find myself expanding because increasing population gives small rewards.

It is very difficult to unlock the cards needed for technological advancement, and it is not really something that you can affect, the 'treasure chest' mechanic feels random and un-rewarding.

Currently the game has many glitches and difficulties. It is SOOOO tedious to reshape the landscape, and it often does not reshape the way you want it to resulting in people getting stuck everywhere.

The Astari (rival tribe) also gain loads of happiness and beat your tribe whenever you save and leave your PC for more than a few hours, even when their entire kingdom is covered in swamp land and they all die every time they leave their houses. If you win people from rivals they do nothing but annoy you for the entire game.

Overall it is a wonderful looking game, with a lot of potential, but can't help but think the PC is an after thought for the developers, and it will all be about buying gems on a mobile phone.

I have had some fun playing it up until this point. I would not recommend paying full price for this game while it is in Early Access, however it could easily be worth the full price when the game is finished.

My recommendation would be to pick up any Civilization game, because while this game looks super cute, right now Civilization does everything this game does better!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Peter Molyneux stated in press and various media before the release of this early access that updates would be completed on a weekly basis. In the several months since then, there has been one feature-adding update, and one bug-fixing update. This, and many other Steam Early Access games, essentially amount to scams.

The game itself is interesting and fun, and it has the *potential* for greatness, but it's not likely to come to fruition in any reasonable amount of time at this point. I regret buying into the hype. If you do decide to buy this game, wait until it's completely done and let these guys find funding other than through Steam purchases.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Godus – a game that you buy to play it 10 minutes per day. Because it does not let you play it when you want to play it.

Godus is fun for the first 30 minutes. Building a small village, collecting belief, sculpting the landscape and playing little mini-games can be fun. But after that you need to expand and you want to create bigger settlements.

Well, too bad … it takes 20 minutes to complete a single building. Belief generation takes even longer. Later in game you also need to farm wheat to be able to create buildings. That is where the fun begins. Wheat takes up to several days until it can be harvested.

After two hours your gameplay is as following: Start the game, collect belief, collect all the wheat and build as many as five new buildings with it. Wait for the next day to repeat that process.

It feels like a mobile game, with the same amount of waiting. It is pure cheekiness that this game was ever released for PC.

Stay away.
