reviewText:
Early Access Review

To start off I do think Godus has a lot of potential but with that being said I really don't feel like it is taking advantage of this golden opportunity to make an amazing game. For starters...

The 41% of the game that we are able to play at this moment is very fragmented meaning there are a lot of loose ends that have yet to be completed which is reasonable to a point. This game is in beta I know, but usually more content is released in a beta version.

The game mechanics are tedious and boring. I have gotten to the farthest point in the game so far (near the end of the bronze age) and not much has changed since the beginning of the game. You drag land to make plots so your villagers can hide out in your house and only come out once you have cleared yet another plot. Furthermore you spend a fat portion of your time clearing rocks and destroying trees.

It lacks in appealing and detailed aesthetics. Trees and rocks are nice but the game is missing many major elements that could make the landscape much more appealing to look at.

The card system is very annoying and it takes way too much time to increase population and gather food.

There aren't enough powers. I know more will be added but for a beta there are not nearly enough.

In the end this game is still very much a work in progress. What has been released is very boring in fact the only fun part was raining meteorites down on my below average intelligence, house dwelling ♥♥♥♥♥ known as followers.

My advice to you is buy the game while it is cheap and wait until the full game comes out or make sure your investment is secure and only buy it once you know they haven't abandoned the game and it's fully completed, keep in mind it will be much more expensive at this point if it is any good.
voteText: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Its nice at first look and it is kinda interesting for a while.
Love the graphics, sounds de feel of it.

Just ... its not a game.

After some time, it tastes like work, repetitive, boring and mindless work. With little or no reward at all.
In fact, you mostly hope to recieve no rewards coz that will pop on your screen with stuff you dont need, and have no use.

And, if you dare goining into the battle arena, but for little differences, is just close to the same, and sometimes even worst.

What you get from Godus now is a pretty nice base for a good game, some mechanics that kinda makes sense, but thats all. I hope to see a real game emerging from that, but thats not it just now.

I really belive theres space for huge improvement, this is not a hopeless game, lets check what happens in future.

reviewText:

There's not a lot I can say about Godus as it has been a colossal dissapointment. Even after the promised updates to add complexity and remove frustration from the game, Peter Molyneux has just added to his far reaching repotoir of hyperbole and false promises that have been voiced this past decade. To save wasting my time on writing a full and critical review on this alpha title (I admit, it is still in alpha so there is always the chance for things to change, but the fact that they called their last radicual update a huge change is quite an obnoxious joke and I don't see anything siginifcant changing) I will summarise what the experience amounts to. It is an iOS game through and through that is being developed and playtested on PC. It's overly simplistic interface leaves a lot to be desired by a PC gamer, and clearly is designed with a touch interface in mind.

The past complaint by players of how the game involved Too much clicking" has largely been ignored

you don't want to be waiting for 80% of your gaming experience.

TL:DR?
Godus is shaping up to be a cow-clicker that has yet to be monitised

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TLDR: Spent $20 on this game … it was $19.50 more than I should have spent.

I tried to like this game, I really did ... but to be perfectly honest, I found Cookie Clicker (http://orteil.dashnet.org/cookieclicker/) to have more depth and entertainment value.  Granted this game is still in development ... but unless its gutted and rebuilt from the ground up it will never amount to anything.

- Resources comprise of faith" and "gems" ... faith requires you to click each house to gather it ... and you have hundreds of houses ... it is repetitive and boring.  Gems on the other hand wreaks of micro-transactions.

- Upgrade tree is … well … not a upgrade tree.  You do not get to pick which path you take
date:
and advancements are based on these stupid little cards that pop up and cover your screen for way too long.

- Land masses are procedurally generated and look amazing but sculpting the landscape for use of your villagers is tedious and annoying.

- Once you start the game there is no way of going back and restarting.  There is no ability to reset to try things differently.  This sucks alot when you spend a bunch of gems early on just to find out that you need them for something else and have no way of un-doing your previous actions."

the game itself is not worth 20 usd. heck maybe a 2d god game like reus would be more fun since you dont actually interact and have to spoonfeed the followers". well enough of the rants......

quick summary will be that this game will be just a waste of time and money unless they add something thats significantly useful after the early access otherwise im probably never touching this again. i basically spent about 7-8 hours digging up the moutains flattening the lands and adding lands for people to move into without any changes happening... other than being able to build bigger houses. for more in depth explanation feel free to read thoughts below.


i brought the game mainly because of the "god" features in all the screenshots and stuff thinking that the gameplay will allow me to war
date: destroy the civilizations and such just for the fun of it. honestly i should have read the reviews without just looking at the screenshots. the game is extremely repetitive. you basically just "sculpt" the land for your "followers" to move into.\n\nto "sculpt" the land you have to have something like beliefs
recommended: which is the purple thing on top of the houses you see in the screenshots. so basically
hoursPlayed: you clear trees and rocks get beliefs from the houses. and use them to sculpt the land and build houses for your followers. not sure about the lightning and fire thing destroying the civilazations since i havent unlocked that... almost 10 hours into the gameplay might i add the waring part you see on the screenshots? thats just vs the npcs and thats not even always and in addition to that you dont really do anything once a certain goal or time is achieved all your "followers" leave thier house to attack the other "gods" "followers". i cleared like 10 stages into it and now i have to pass a "bronze" era before i can continue playing. i cant even replay old modes so its pretty much back to sculpting and sculpting.... like i would even waste any more time on it\n\nthe card things they say? well the cards are hidden in the land and rivers so you basically dig into them to find it.... its not actually even useful. heck it dosent even affect your gameplay. everything i have so far 10 hours into the gameplay just allows the "followers" to build even bigger houses."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Why is this mobile game on a PC platform store?

--

2 years later and the game is by the Dev's estimate about 50% done.
The Kickstarter page and Steam Store page seem to offer Godus as a God game with battles against rival tribes and control over the tasks of your followers. This is not what the game is.

Essentially, it's a cow-clicker where you click, wait for the timer to reset, then click again. That's it.

I've played this game for about 70 hours - mostly whilst watching something in another window - trying to find out when the game opens up and gets interesting. I have concluded that it doesn't.
voteText: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really wanted to like Godus.  I did!  I bought into Molyneux's dreaming, and his verbally spinning golden threads, but what he's produced is unworthy of Bullfrog's legacy.  He seems to assume that people really, really like clicking on things, and I guess that, if you do, this might be the game for you, but for anyone else, this is completely not.  Every update, every patch, every redesign has done absolutely nothing to adress this games ill-concieved foundation.  And outside of this relentless clicking, the gameplay is a linear slog attempting to give you the illusion of choice where the glaring reality is that there is none.

To the devs:   Your game is painfully boring.  Looking for these resource stickers is NOT fun, and applying them is meaningless busy work.  Stop with the clicking on these damn huts.  Just give us the mana! Let us play, and get these idiotic Farmvill clicking antics out of your heads!

Ok, Ive put a ton of hours into this game since buying it a YEAR ago. It had its problems back then and it still does now. Instead now this feels like a game i would play on my phone. Atleast (regardless how broken it was back then) when i first got this game a year ago, i had something to do and mindlessly sculpting land into what i wanted did have its charm. Now however i find myself waiting for belief, to rope my villagers into a pit for gems. Using the gems to buy more belief, then to rinse and repeat as i wait for HOURS for wheat to grow, to use up right as it does to build one or two more houses, so i can kill more people to... do it all again. That is all this game is. Waiting and killing people for gems. This is just such a broken game now and for it to still not be done is just f*cking mind blowing. Im done waiting. After a year and only getting what 10% more of a game that cant pick what it wants to be? No Thank You. Don't Buy This Game. Its not worth the time or money i put into it so don't waste yours either.
0/10 wouldn't play again

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Why is this mobile game on a PC platform store?

--

2 years later and the game is by the Dev's estimate about 50% done.
The Kickstarter page and Steam Store page seem to offer Godus as a God game with battles against rival tribes and control over the tasks of your followers. This is not what the game is.

Essentially, it's a cow-clicker where you click, wait for the timer to reset, then click again. That's it.

I've played this game for about 70 hours - mostly whilst watching something in another window - trying to find out when the game opens up and gets interesting. I have concluded that it doesn't.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A game that doesn't develop in real time. It develops per click. For a god game, you're supposed to influence and then sit back, letting the world behave how it wants to behave.

But no, this is a clicker. If you don't click, you don't progress. Click click click click. That's the only gameplay element here. Yeah you can move layers of earth, but you're only doing that to create building space, which happens after you click click click click.

This is not a god game, it is a click game. Until it is real time, dynamic and a living world that just evolves with a player only nudging and influencing trends this game is heading to a terrible finished product. And it is a beta, meaning features are locked. The game won't be improving...oh damn!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was attracted by the description of GOD GAME" But it doesn't feel even close to any god game I've ever played... and not in a good way at all.

Ok
date:
I will cut them SOME slack because it is in early development but still.. the direction the game has been going so far is not really entertaining at all.

The map/land is made out of layers and layers of land which to expand your "civilization" you have to pull it apart to make it flat. You cannot pull land unless you have enough belief which you have to WAIT for it to regenerate on your already constructed settlements. The mechanics of this is extremely tedius and boring. Eventually you can unlock ways to destroy your own settlements as if they thought this would be fun.. it's not. It feels like an evolved version of farmville but with a fake promise of "civilization building".

Seriously
recommended: do not pay money for this game. IFFFF They improve this game and actually point it into the direction of a God Game

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Populous, Dungeon Keeper, Dungeon Keeper 2 (Bullfrog Software) Basically everything pre-Lionhead software days that Peter Molyneux touched was gold. Thinking about it, I even liked Black & White. At this point, I should know better. Peter Molyneux is a genius at selling games that just don't exist, and now with Godus he has really done it.  Maybe I feel burned that I spent 18 hours trying to reach locations in the game that are impossible to reach (without hacking).

That said. There is promise here, If updates were to arrive. Even a a production update at this point would be better than nothing.

I wonder if Peter Molyneux and PT Barnum are related.
voteText: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ignore the video, any pictures and any comments from the devs at the moment. The game is currently frustrating and very lacking. While it still has potential to be a fun little god game, it would seem that is a very very long way off and in it's current for it is not worth paying ANY money for.

The game lacks any real goal or aim, the terraforming is clunky and not easy to use, being unable to rotate the camera, accuratly drag bits of land and having to unlock further tools in a very slow process makes it even worse. Dwellings cannot upgrade themselves so frequently have to destroy and start again. You are forced into a very linear process of population growth, side games or specific area population in order to progress. The AI... never progresses past the nealithic age, they'll still randomly stop working or wander off throught the game.

All of this coupled with the fact there are some game crashing bugs, save loss moments and possibly more updates that will cause you to loose any saved maps means this is a game to avoid still and for a long time to come. The game is possibly the poster child for bad examples of early access.

(P.S the game will also make you grumpy, because if you play it you'll see the potential and want to play what the game should be at the end of all the mess)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't know where to begin. There are multiple horrible problems with this game and they are all related:

1. Heritage
The game was developed for mobile phones and Windows.
It very obviously shows. Not just in the gameplay (I'll come to this later), but also in the UI and the controls which are terribad and only use one mouse button from what I can tell.

2. Controls aka digging sucks"
The game is built around the mechanic of modifying the land your people are living on. This wouldn't be so bad (just look at From Dust) if it was actually fun. But there are a few problems that make it un-fun in every way possible.
The main one of which is that it controls just terribly. With the new update they at least made you stronger so you don't have to click a hundred times to move some dirt around.
But the other problem is that not only you can only move one "layer" at once (which is bad enough as it is)
date: but it's also extremely hard to know which layer the game will think you want to modify which is doubly frustrating because it costs "belief" (the resource generated by your people
recommended:
also the only real resource)

3. Gameplay
There are no resources like in B&W or other RTS games. You just have to get belief
hoursPlayed: which is possible to get just by waiting. The game doesn't even have to be running. You just have to check in from time to time to pop the belief bubbles in your village like in Facebook or mobile free to play games.\nThe entire gameplay consists of getting upgrades for your people. This works by unlocking unlock cards by getting more population which you get by flattening land (at this point I want to remind you of point 2) and clicking on icons that pop up over your houses to build more houses. Houses are free
voteText: the only cost they have is that they take up time to build (only a few seconds) and some flat land which you have to painstakenly flatten.\nAfter you repeated the above process enough times to get enough houses and followers you finally get an unlock card. But to actually use it you have to spend research resources on them. These are little stickers with themes like technology or socializing. By dragging enough of them on a card you get its advantage/upgrade.\nDoesn't sound half bad
helpfulPercent: right? Well
votesHelpful: actually it sounds half bad
votesTotal:
but it's actually full-bad. The reason for that is because of how you get those stickers:
You have to get them out of treasure chests burried deep within the terrain around your village. This means you have to expand your village (i.e. flatten more land->build more houses) to get more land to find treasure chests in. Once you found a treasure chest (you can tell where they are by the little floating leafs above the ground) and dug it out you get a random sticker. At this point I want to remind you of point 2 again because this is basically all you'll be doing.
That's all there is to the gameplay...

4. Graphics
It actually looks quite nice. I like the graphics style. I just wanted to end with something positive."
